itemRows.title: Item 5
itemRows.content: This is a caption for a video clip.

itemRows.title: Introduction
itemRows.content:
“Point of View is worth 80 IQ points”
—Alan Kay

When Covid arrived, many of us went on a learning frenzy. Now with the situation in the Ukraine, we find ourselves trying to understand what’s happening and the history that led up to it. I’m fascinated to realize how much I’m relying on text — articles, essays, twitter feeds etc. — to provide the nuanced exploration of complex and abstract ideas i’m looking for, practically in real-time. Video may help me identify with the suffering of the Ukranian people, but it seems to skim along the surface, manipulating emotions rather than digging deep for understanding.

Yesterday I read four articles, quite different in perspective and even topic, which I thought gave me some insight into what’s going on. What’s remarkable is that when compared to the limited range of voices of the pre-internet era, these four articles are only a tiny fraction of the breathtaking range of voices now available on the internet. And this is right on time because the complexity of the current moment is such that we need a broad array of lenses through which we can look; not that truth is relative, but rather that truth is inevitably a collage of perspectives which depend on the collision of multiple viewpoints.

Thanks to the Internet Archive’s Wayback Machine, I’m putting the four articles here for two reasons. Some of you may find them interesting and worth the read. And also, as a way of connecting to the ongoing conversation about the evolution of media in the networked era. What better time to talk than right now when we’re in the middle of it.
References:
Which was archived because of several cool archiving projects:
And this Tweet:

itemRows.title: Saved from the Fire: a Triangle Employee Escapes
itemRows.content:
Ida Seltzer recalls being spared the fate of many of her co-workers during the great Triangle Shirtwaist Company fire in March 1911. She had been fired only the before for refusing to work because her father was ill.

Seltzer: In 1911 I went into work to the Triangle and at that time, I made there already $12 a week. The shop there, was tremendous, it was three or four flights. In the shop, you know, we were piecework. It was very, very hard work. And it was in a terrible, terrible sweatshop. It was absolutely unbearable. Production there was like, they were standing in the back of you, and watching you every minute, what you worked and they drive like a slave. The doors were locked. No fire escape.

Every night, when we used to go out of the shop, it used to be a group of girls are there from the shop, like you know, hired that they should examine you, your bosom, your panties, you’re anything, if you don’t take out any lace, or cotton, or a blouse. They used to, the men used to be examined and the women used to be examined.

At that time, it was on Friday and I couldn’t work overtime — my father was very sick, really sick, he got emphysema and he coughed an awful lot, and I had a lot of problems and couldn’t work, you know, overtime. They expected me to work. So I came to the foreman and I said to him, “I can’t work overtime, I. . . “ He said, “Get out! And don’t come back in tomorrow.” so I didn’t, so I went out . . .

Interviewer: How much time of overtime where are you expected to work?

Seltzer: well, you hadda work, you used to work from six till eight o’clock. You know, till you get home, it was nine o’clock, because the walking home two hours . . .

Interviewer: and what kind of work did you do there, specifically?

Seltzer: Specif . . . a machine. You know, working a machine, blouses. And I came home. And tomorrow was the fire. And that time, I’ll never forget it. I . . . you sit with young people nine months, machine by machine you know. Others, the right machine is from this side, and across the way it was another machine. And you got acquainted for nine months with young people. They had, some of them, had diamond rings - they're supposed to get married in June. The boys used to work daytime and go at night to school and they had the hopes they’ll be an engineer, they’ll be a doctor, they’ll be a lawyer – they’ll be something. You know, young, intelligent children, each and everyone of them, was no dumbbells.

And the fire broke out. They locked, the doors were locked. There was no fire escape we had to escape, or no door to open. 146 children were burned and not to recognize and except…

Hundreds and hundreds of people were taken to the hospitals. They spraying from the windows, down, you know? Oh, it was a tragedy for years and years.

The Immigrant Experience, produced by Gail Pellet (New York: WBAI, 1976).

itemRows.title: Interview With Ida Seltzer, A Survivor Of The Triangle Fire 1911
A century of women : the most influential events in twentieth-century women's history
Introduction
itemRows.content: I went and searched the Internet Archive for Emily Dickinson's poem "Faith is a Fine Invention" curious about how much diversity there might be in the results. For a very familiar poem, there's a surprising amount of variation!

itemRows.title: Item 3
itemRows.content:
A 1996 edition of Dickinson. Here we have some italics and capitals and a dash, the editor maybe having gone back to the original. "Faith" is in quotation marks.

What's also interesting here is that the second line is different: "when Gentlemen can see," not "for Gentlemen who see".

itemRows.title: Item 5
itemRows.content: An issue of Mad from June 1972 shows Pope Paul VI peering through a microscope.

itemRows.title: Item 7
itemRows.content: An anthology from 1994 has no italics, no quotation marks, no capitalized words.

itemRows.title: Item 9
itemRows.content: Monarch Notes normalizes Dickinson in quoting her: her words don't look any different than the academic writing around them.

itemRows.title: Item 11
itemRows.content:
Mabel Loomis Todd's 1893 edition of Dickinson's poem, ostensibly where most of these came from. Note the lack of capitalization; nobody follows the initial dropcap and small caps, and the French spacing before the exclamation point seems like a dead-end.

There are no quotation marks around "Faith".

itemRows.title: Item 13
itemRows.content: A 1964 edition goes back to the first word in small caps.

itemRows.title: Item 15
itemRows.content: Another Selected Poems from 1997. This one has the italics and the dash, though it's not identical: there's also a space before the dash.

itemRows.title: Item 16
itemRows.content: The Harvard Medical Alumni Bulletin from 1982 decides to forego punctuation and capitalization and italicize the whole thing.

itemRows.title: WikiSource, 2008
itemRows.content: In 2008, WikiSource italicized Microscopes but not "see" and had a space before the dash. There are no exclamation marks. The second line is "When Gentlemen can see —".

itemRows.title: Item 20
itemRows.content: By 2020, Wikisource had italicized see as well as Microscopes and also dropped a dash and added some exclamation marks. There are quotation marks, but in the second line, the older "For Gentlemen who see!" is being used.

itemRows.title: First Amendment
itemRows.content: Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances.

itemRows.title: Second Amendment
itemRows.content: A well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed.

itemRows.title: Third Amendment
itemRows.content: No Soldier shall, in time of peace be quartered in any house, without the consent of the Owner, nor in time of war, but in a manner to be prescribed by law.

itemRows.title: Fourth Amendment
itemRows.content: The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated, and no Warrants shall issue, but upon probable cause, supported by Oath or affirmation, and particularly describing the place to be searched, and the persons or things to be seized.

itemRows.title: Fifth Amendment
itemRows.content: No person shall be held to answer for a capital, or otherwise infamous crime, unless on a presentment or indictment of a Grand Jury, except in cases arising in the land or naval forces, or in the Militia, when in actual service in time of War or public danger; nor shall any person be subject for the same offence to be twice put in jeopardy of life or limb; nor shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself, nor be deprived of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law; nor shall private property be taken for public use, without just compensation.

itemRows.title: Introduction
itemRows.content: I went and searched the Internet Archive for Emily Dickinson's poem "Faith is a Fine Invention" curious about how much diversity there might be in the results. For a very familiar poem, there's a surprising amount of variation!

itemRows.title: Item 3
itemRows.content:
A 1996 edition of Dickinson. Here we have some italics and capitals and a dash, the editor maybe having gone back to the original. "Faith" is in quotation marks.

What's also interesting here is that the second line is different: "when Gentlemen can see," not "for Gentlemen who see".

itemRows.title: New Item
itemRows.content: McLuhan once said ‘we’re driving faster and faster into the future but steering only by looking through the rear-view mirror.’ And we can think of a corner being turned into the actual modern era. I just gave a talk in Korea whose title was The computer revolution hasn’t happened yet. I would say that it won’t have happened until people start using the computer to start dealing with thought vectors and concept space and dealing with the idea that you can have active dynamic models of the things your trying to represent.”

itemRows.title: The book of probes : Marshall McLuhan, David Carson
Alan Kay introduces his talk
itemRows.thumbnail: https://ia601503.us.archive.org/29/items/alan-kay-introduces-his-talk-at-mit-symposium-on-vannevar-bush-1995/Alan Kay Introduces his talk at MIT symposium on  Vannevar Bush 1995.mov

itemRows.title: Item 1
itemRows.content:
In 1995 MIT and Brown University sponsored a symposium honoring the work of Vannevar Bush. Alan Kay’s presentation focused on the contributions of the early pioneers whose work in the 60s had been inspired in part by Vannevar Bush’s seminal 1945 article, As We May Think.

To explore, click the links.

itemRows.title: Alan Kay quote
itemRows.content: “Knowing more than your own field is really helpful. I’ve always thought one of the reasons the 60s was interesting is that no one was a computer scientist back then. And everyone who came into it, came in with lots of other knowledge and interests. Because of that, when they tried to figure out what computers were, the only place they could go to for analogies were other areas, so we got some extremely interesting ideas from that.”

itemRows.title: Mindstorms: children, computers, and powerful ideas
Alan Kay discusses the role of JCR Licklider and ARPA
itemRows.thumbnail: https://ia601409.us.archive.org/3/items/alan-kay-discusses-marvin-minsky-at-mit-symposium-on-vannevar-bush-1995/Alan Kay discusses Marvin Minsky at MIT symposium on  Vannevar Bush 1995.mov

itemRows.title: Item 8
itemRows.content: “Typical Marvin comment: ‘You don’t understand anything if you only understand it one way’”

itemRows.title: Item 3
itemRows.content:
Movie Manual

When I first saw Dave Backer's Movie Manual at MIT it blew my mind on two counts. Anti-aliasing had just been developed in the lab and this was the first time anyone had seen decent looking text on a TV screen (the quality of the video doesn’t come close to how good it looked in situ). Also the first time the video appears on what otherwise looks like a normal book page (about 2:20 in the video) it expanded our notion of the page to include audio and video — i.e. the affordances of a book but with the addition of time-based media.

itemRows.title: As We May Think in Wikipedia
As We May Think (The Atlantic Monthly, 1945)
Alan Kay discusses the role of JCR Licklider and ARPA
itemRows.thumbnail: https://ia601409.us.archive.org/3/items/alan-kay-discusses-marvin-minsky-at-mit-symposium-on-vannevar-bush-1995/Alan Kay discusses Marvin Minsky at MIT symposium on  Vannevar Bush 1995.mov

itemRows.title: J. C. R. Licklider on Wikipedia
Item 5
itemRows.content:
“I think it's true of most of the people i think of as the great people in the 60s is that they really wanted it all.”

—Alan remarking on the early pioneer’s expansive view of what was possible and important.

itemRows.title: Alan Kay discusses Ivan Sutherland & Sketchpad
itemRows.thumbnail: https://ia601409.us.archive.org/3/items/alan-kay-discusses-marvin-minsky-at-mit-symposium-on-vannevar-bush-1995/Alan Kay discusses Marvin Minsky at MIT symposium on  Vannevar Bush 1995.mov

itemRows.title: Some Reflections On Early History By J. C. R. Licklider ( VPRI 0093)
Item 8
itemRows.content: Alan Kay on ARPA: “Their basic idea was to fund people instead of projects — one of the great ideas of all time — and fund directions instead of goals. I don’t think anyone else would have funded Engelbart in those days. It’s a real pity that the ARPA funding from the 60s didn’t carry over to the 70s; if it had i think history would have been quite different today. Becuase sometimes the people who can see the farthest are the ones who are the most difficult for the bean counters to understand”

itemRows.title: Introduction
itemRows.content:
There are a number of segments in which the stamp “FAKE” is emblazoned over images of dead bodies in Bucha and other images, including Zelenskyy.

One short segment includes footage from a Live For America interview of Marjorie Taylor Greene by Jeremy Herrell in which she is heard to say, “They have been calling us Nazis for past 5 years, guess what there are real Nazis in Ukraine” “The Democrats are courting real Nazis in Ukraine.”

Background on these new collections

Mindful of the ravages of the war in Ukraine and state controlled Russian media’s agendas, we are not planning to bring widespread attention to these archival research offerings. However, we welcome journalists and other researchers to explore what we are offering and would appreciate feedback on how we can better meet their needs.

Unlike the TV News Archive, the three Russian language channels are not searchable by captions. There are no captions, we don’t have Russian-to-English speech-to-text software. Currently, there is a 12-hour lag between broadcast time and availability for viewing. We don’t have program title information, so we divide all the broadcast content into 1/2-hour increments. We offer thumbnail images for each 1-minute segment.

  • Russia-1 TV collection (12-hr delay in playability)
  • NTV collection (12-hr delay in playability)
  • Channel One collection (12-hr delay in playability)

itemRows.title: Item 3
itemRows.content: War coverage, CNN excerpt at 11:14 about Russian atrocities

itemRows.title: Item 4
itemRows.content: War coverage, CNN excerpt at 11:45 with former NATO Supreme Allied Commander

itemRows.title: Item 4
itemRows.content: War coverage, CNN excerpt at 11:45 with former NATO Supreme Allied Commander

itemRows.title: Item 4
itemRows.content: Marjorie Taylor Green (US podcast) replayed: "They have been calling us Nazis for past 5 years, guess what there are real Nazis in Ukraine"

itemRows.title: Item 4
itemRows.content: Pentagon briefing at 2:09, CNN excerpt "Russia invades Ukraine" at 2:10

itemRows.title: Item 1
itemRows.content:
If the United States had a tradition of recognizing individuals as "national treasures," media archaeologist, Rick Prelinger would be one of my first nominees. Over the decades Rick rescued 60,000 industrial and educational films, many literally from the dumpster, that together tell a story which is quite different than the "official" Hollywood version. What Rick understood was that the narrative in these "ephemeral" films, which were never intended to be saved for future watching. . . was in many ways a more honest portrayal of the culture than the comedies and dramas on TV and movie screens.

Rick gave his collection to the Library of Congress and also made much of it available at the Internet Archive. But before that, Rick curated a two-hour collection of films which shine a light on the darkness of mid-20th century American culture. Voyager published these on laserdisc and videotape in 1988 and on CD-ROM in the early 90s.

itemRows.title: Item 6
itemRows.content: “Papert had another profound idea. Whatever the computer was it wasn’t really a tool or even a vehicle in the sense of being an automobile as compared to IBM’s railroads. Papert thought of it as being a medium for powerful ideas”

itemRows.title: Item 4
itemRows.content: “What Engelbart brought was not just a vision of interacting with a system, but he had a philosophical underpinning.”

itemRows.title: Bob Stein introduces Rick Prelinger's Ephemeral Films project
Zoodoo
itemRows.content: Zoodoo was Alex Itin’s first work in TK3. Voyager had published a poetry anthology by Ron Mann featuring 24 poets performing their work often, as was the case with Amiri Baraka with musical accompaniment. Alex took the film’s audio track and added a series of paintings inspired by words. The rhythm of Baraka’s delivery allowed the user a moment to look at the painting and then reveal the text of the next stanza.

itemRows.title: Bob Stein Introduces The TK 3 Work Of Alex Itin
itemRows.thumbnail: https://ia601409.us.archive.org/2/items/bob-stein-introduces-the-tk-3-work-of-alex-itin/Bob Stein introduces the TK3 work of Alex Itin.mov

itemRows.title: Item 6
itemRows.content:
arc along the watchtower

arc along the watchtower is Alex’s most complex TK3 work — two brothers confront the reality of their father’s death told in alternating spurts of film, painting and audio.  two versions below, the first simply goes page by page letting the video on each page play to the end before proceeding; the other just the paintings with their bits of the conversation.

itemRows.title: Item 8
itemRows.content:
Morococo

Words and Paintings by Alex Itin, Music by Javier Hernandez Miyares. The reader can go page by page sequentially or click on hot spots which make pre-ordained hyper-jumps through the text.

Alex’s statement about Morocco

Morococo was a text from an Arabic school book.  Arabic is beautiful even if illegible to me. Calligraphy.  Calligraffiti.  I had this sense that what I loved about American painting had come out of a sort of perverse intellectual reaction to WW2.  There was the expressionism of German painting mixed with the zen gestural brush work of illegible Japanese poetry.  You become the enemy you kill.  You become the New York School. I imagined white intellectuals at say Columbia hired by the OSS to translate German and Japanese going down town to drink with the painters at the cedar bar listening to Jazz and trying to wrap their heads around the enemy and I imagined a Dutch like deKooning could be a nexus for Americans to get it or if not get it but feel it.  In the way that jazz can be felt pentatonic to 12 note scale.l. Blue Bach.  It was a mourning for the dead ones you had to kill.  Or so I thought and to be frank still do.respect the dead.  Respect your enemy.  Respect your enemy’s dead.  Try to sing a song about it.  It’s kind of that simple.

I’d graduated from college into the IRAQ war.  This unknown known was on my head and I could feel it was the crisis point of my generation that is called X.  I’d read John Mcafee’s book on the Arc of Binding Energy and had a real sense that there was a thing in the wind.   It was coming.  It came,  but not as bad as I was fearing.  But still the anxiety of history turning.

itemRows.title: Item 9
itemRows.content:
Asi Nisi Masa

Asi Nisi Masa is Alex’s homage to cinema in general and to his favorite eight and a half films, the half being the short children’s film, The Red Balloon; the others — Citizen Kane, 2001: A Space Odyssey, The Third Man, Wild Strawberries, Rear Window, Rashomon, Taxi Driver and 8 1/2. Several years later, Alex used the TK3 version of Asi Nisi Masa as a central prop or character in a live performance in which he told a haunting story of his father’s death.  The video of that performance is posted below the video of the TK3 work.

The rhythm of Baraka’s delivery allowed the user a moment to look at the painting and then reveal the text of the next stanza.

itemRows.title: Item 9
itemRows.content:
Asi Nisi Masa

itemRows.title: Item 11
itemRows.content:
A note about what TK3 could and could not do.

The goal of TK3 was to enable anyone to assemble media elements via simple drag and drop. Although the TK3 authoring environment provided pre-defined templates, in terms of graphic design, users had complete control over every single pixel, even to the extent of designing custom looks for each of the the built in tools (navigation, search, note-taking etc.) One important feature TK3 lacked was the ability to turn pages according to a time-line. Thus in the Alex Itin works shown here, the page turns are not automatic.

itemRows.title: Item 11
itemRows.content:
Alex’s Introduction

Where was I:  When I got to New York after fleeing Connecticut death I was temping at a grey ad agency and in Park Slope and I had musician friends from Dumbo who would do DJ events and live music and I found myself reworking the figurative language idea with books I found in the streets of Brooklyn.  In those days all writers lived in Park Slope and their libraries over flowed to their neighbors by way of the stoops and sidewalks.  In some ways Park Slope was an enormous lending library, but always there was the rain.  I’d seen holocausts of drowned books.  It did not seem such a sin to take them and use them as room to rehearse the figure.

I had a deal with myself then and partly now and this slows me down but, if I hadn’t read it and loved it I couldn’t kill it.  I could only draw in books I loved. I was an old yeller even in my youth.  So I did a long series of drawing nights at the Galapagos club in Williamsburg where I would take a text:  say Frankenstein on Halloween and try to draw the room.  Everyone in it.  It had some relation to Joyce and the idea that if you put a focus on anyone on the street there was a novel there.  We are all a great epic story and also I suppose sort of boring and a sameness of crowd. Also if you obscured some or most of the text a randomly generated poem would appear in the margins. It was  maybe Bowie by Burroughs by way of the Dadas….. or the obvious.  Anyway if you knew the book even just a few of the words would glow with the nostalgia of a lost love, or so I supposed.  The DJ said this is so great because no one reads anymore.

I would attempt to sell these pages for 5 dollars which was the price of a beer at Galapagos. Mostly people just bought me a beer and took a page as souvenir,  or just bought me a  beer and listened to me talk.  There was a large element of performance;  some didacticism,  some advocacy for things I liked.  I hoped people who took a page would feel compelled to read the book it was on.  This was naive I think and not all that many took pages any way so soon I had a large library of drawings.

I met Bob Stein at an open studios event where I’d put up an epic floor to ceiling wall installation all these book pages.  The building was a gun power labyrinth of GET SMART passages and doors and long halls.  I don’t think he saw the installation,  but he found me drawing in the pages of Hemingway at the bar in my friends loft.  He said, “You are the guy I’m looking for”.

I said, “what do you mean?”

He said, “I’m a digital publisher.

I said, “Oh I think you’re the guy I’m looking for”

Because earlier a DJ had told me everything should be on the computer.

itemRows.title: Item 13
itemRows.content:
arc along the watchtower

Arc Along the Watchtower is Alex’s most complex TK3 work — two brothers confront the reality of their father’s death told in alternating spurts of film, painting and audio. The first version goes page by page with all the video; the other is shorter as it proceeds with just the paintings and the audio.

itemRows.title: Arc Along The Watchtower Stills + Audio
Item 1
itemRows.content: THIS IS A TEST

itemRows.title: Item 1
itemRows.content:
HYPERCARD:

Steve Jobs Killed It . . . But not in a good way

Apple's introduction of HyperCard at Macworld in August 1987 wins my vote for one of the most exciting events in computing history. Bill Atkinson, HyperCard's architect, wanted to democratize computing by creating a platform for ordinary people to “make things.” Hypercard, enabled users to create stacks of (virtual) cards which could be linked to each other in different ways. The six buttons in the photo, celebrating the idea of linking one idea to another (hypertext)were given away at the Macworld launch.

Teachers were the first to glom onto HyperCard, yielding an explosion of creativity as tens of thousands of non-programmers were suddenly empowered to assemble credible content on their own.

Much of HyperCard's power came from Dan Winkler's plain-english programming language — HyperTalk. I'll never forget my own glee when I made a button to advance to the next page by simply adding the simple script "Go Next Card" to a graphic of a forward facing arrow. This was heady stuff for someone who practically failed "physics for poets." Nothing I ever made with HyperCard was good enough to publish, but I was able to create first drafts which my dear colleagues Steve Riggins (and later Colin Holgate) turned into something useful and wonderful. I'll make separate entries later on for some of the things we made.

Two more things:

Bill Atkinson said that the idea for HyperCard came to him during an acid trip.

One of the very first things Steve Jobs did when he returned to Apple was to kill HyperCard. It was a sad day and I trust history will judge him harshly for this.

itemRows.title: Item 4
itemRows.content: A HyperCard stack which conveniently describes what HyperCard is and what it can do.

itemRows.title: The Complete Hitchhiker's Guide To The Galaxy (Hypercard)

itemRows.title: Item 4
itemRows.content: This is a Hypercard stack which conveniently explains how it works.

itemRows.title: The Complete Hitchhiker's Guide To The Galaxy (Hypercard)
Item 6
itemRows.content: The very first electronic books were created in HyperCard in 1992. The first three were Douglas Adams' Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, Martin Gardner's Annotated Alice in Wonderland and Michael Crichton's Jurassic Park. Douglas Adams' created an audio promo which many years later was attached to the animation on the right.

itemRows.title: Cd Companion To Beethoven's Ninth Symphony By Robert Winter ( 480p)
Item 8
itemRows.content: Voyager's CD Companion to Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, by Robert Winter, the first commercially viable CD-ROM, published in 1988 was created in Hypercard. This is a promo video.
